column4: Yeah. Like, I keep hearing about release cycles, stable vs. unstable releases, LTS (I know what it stands for), etc. etc.
I don't understand the context/significance of these things. It's confusing me.
Where can I find out more?
Basically, where can I learn more about how Ubuntu is developed and why it's based on Debian?
And the logic behind the development choices.
Hahaha.
I'm having a hard time wrapping my head around the purpose of these.
I don't really get what it is.
Thanks for the response.
My question is what exactly does "supported" mean in this context?
you get updates
software updates, yes and people in here will help you
regular version 6 months
every 4th release is an LTS
correct
most of third party is "supported" by the community
they go End of Life
you can still technically use them but you won't get updates
you can upgrade or clean install
the closest you'd get to rolling release is by using the dev releases, which isn't really recommended unless you have a spare system that you don't rely on
it's not that bad having a slightly out-of-date solitaire game
